contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox protected area of Australia | name = Lake Torrens National Park | iucn_category = Ia | image = Australia_Locator_Map.svg | caption = | locator_x = 168 | locator_y = 145 | nearest_town_or_city = [[Woomera, South Australia|Woomera]] | coordinates = {{coord|31|02|40|S|137|51|35|E|}} | area = 5,677 km² | established = 1991 | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | managing_authorities = [[Department for Environment and Heritage]] | official_site = [http://www.parks.sa.gov.au/publish/groups/public/@parks/@northernflinders/documents/all/parks_pdfs_lake_torrens_np.pdf Lake Torrens National Park] pdf }} '''Lake Torrens National Park''' is a national park in [[South Australia]], 345 km north of [[Adelaide]]. ==Environment== ===Geology=== [[Lake Torrens]] is a 5,700 square kilometre [[endorheic]] saline [[Rift (geology)|rift]] lake in [[South Australia]],and is located in southern Australia. It forms part of the same rift valley that includes [[Spencer Gulf]] to the south and is approximately 240 km long. It is in the Lake Torrens National Park, and a permit is required to visit. Lake Torrens is usually a dry salt flat. It has been filled with water only once in the past 150 years - in 1989. ===Birds=== The lake has been identified by [[BirdLife International]] as an [[Important Bird Area]] (IBA) because it supported up to 100,000 breeding [[Banded Stilt]]s during the major filling event of 1989.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.birdata.com.au/iba.vm |title=IBA: Lake Torrens |accessdate=2011-08-01 |work= Birdata |first= |last= |publisher=Birds Australia |date= }}</ref> It may occasionally support over 1% of the world population of [[Red-capped Plover]]s. [[Cinnamon Quail-thrush]]es are also common in the IBA.<ref>BirdLife International. (2011). Important Bird Areas factsheet: Lake Torrens. Downloaded from http://www.birdlife.org on 01/08/2011.</ref> ==History== [[Eyre's 1839 expeditions|Discovered]] by [[Edward John Eyre]] in 1839, for the following twenty years it was believed that Lake Torrens was an enormous horseshoe-shaped saltpan encircling the northern [[Flinders Ranges]] and blocking any path to the interior. The first European to penetrate the mythical barrier was [[A. C. Gregory]] from the north in March 1858; later the same year, an expedition under [[B. H. Babbage]] and [[Peter Egerton Warburton|Major Warburton]] in the north-west also crossed the non-existent barrier near modern [[Marree, South Australia|Marree]]. Eyre's horseshoe lake was actually composed of [[Lake Frome]], [[Lake Callabonna]], [[Lake Blanche]], [[Lake Gregory (South Australia)|Lake Gregory]], [[Lake Eyre|Lake Eyre South]], and Lake Torrens itself. [[File:Gypsum var. selenite from Andamooka Ranges - Lake Torrens area, South Australia.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Gypsum]] var. [[selenite]] from [[Andamooka]] Ranges - Lake Torrens area]] ==See also== * [[Protected areas of South Australia]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{National Parks of South Australia}} [[Category:National parks of South Australia]] [[Category:Lakes of South Australia|Torrens]] [[Category:Endorheic lakes of Australia|Torrens]] [[Category:Rift lakes|Torrens]] [[Category:Aulacogens|Torrens]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 1991]] [[Category:1991 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Far North (South Australia)]] [[Category:Important Bird Areas of South Australia]] {{SouthAustralia-protected-area-stub}} [[be:Возера Торэнс]] [[be-x-old:Торэнс (возера)]] [[cs:Torrensovo jezero]] [[da:Lake Torrens]] [[fr:Lac Torrens]] [[kk:Торренс]] [[lv:Torrensa ezers]] [[lt:Torensas]] [[pl:Torrens (jezioro)]] [[ru:Торренс (озеро)]] [[fi:Torrensjärvi]] [[uk:Торренс (озеро)]]
